1.name: Hydrogen
1.uses: Used in fuel cells, ammonia production, and as a lifting gas in balloons.
1.description: Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, forming the basis of stars and water.

2.name: Helium
2.uses: Used in balloons, cryogenics, and deep-sea diving tanks.
2.description: Helium is the second most abundant element, inert, and produced by stellar fusion.

3.name: Lithium
3.uses: Used in batteries, ceramics, and mood-stabilizing drugs.
3.description: Lithium is the lightest metal, highly reactive, and soft enough to cut with a knife.

4.name: Beryllium
4.uses: Used in aerospace, X-ray equipment, and alloys.
4.description: Beryllium is lightweight, strong, and toxic, requiring careful handling.

5.name: Boron
5.discoverer: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac & Louis Jacques Thénard
5.uses: Used in glass, ceramics, and detergents.
5.description: Boron is a metalloid with unique properties, essential in trace amounts for plants.

6.name: Carbon
6.uses: Used in fuels, steelmaking, and as diamonds in jewelry.
6.description: Carbon is the basis of organic chemistry, existing in multiple forms like graphite and diamond.

7.name: Nitrogen
7.uses: Used in fertilizers, explosives, and as an inert gas.
7.description: Nitrogen makes up 78% of Earth’s atmosphere and is essential for life.

8.name: Oxygen
8.uses: Essential for respiration, used in steelmaking and medical oxygen.
8.description: Oxygen is vital for combustion and life, comprising 21% of Earth’s atmosphere.

9.name: Fluorine
9.uses: Used in refrigerants, toothpaste, and uranium enrichment.
9.description: Fluorine is the most electronegative element, highly reactive and toxic.

10.name: Neon
10.uses: Used in neon signs, lasers, and lighting.
10.description: Neon emits a bright red-orange glow when electrified, used in advertising.

11.name: Sodium
11.uses: Used in soaps, sodium lamps, and as a coolant.
11.description: Sodium is a soft, reactive metal that burns with a yellow flame.

12.name: Magnesium
12.nameOrigin: From Magnesia, a region in Greece
12.uses: Used in alloys, flares, and as a dietary supplement.
12.description: Magnesium burns with a brilliant white light, used in fireworks.

13.name: Aluminum
13.uses: Used in aircraft, packaging, and construction.
13.description: Aluminum is lightweight, durable, and resistant to corrosion.

14.name: Silicon
14.uses: Used in semiconductors, solar cells, and glass.
14.description: Silicon is the second most abundant element in Earth’s crust.

15.name: Phosphorus
15.uses: Used in fertilizers, matches, and detergents.
15.description: Phosphorus glows in the dark and is essential for life.

16.name: Sulfur
16.uses: Used in sulfuric acid, fertilizers, and gunpowder.
16.description: Sulfur has a distinct smell and is found near volcanic regions.

17.name: Chlorine
17.uses: Used in disinfectants, bleach, and plastics.
17.description: Chlorine is a highly reactive gas with a strong odor.

18.name: Argon
18.uses: Used in welding, lighting, and as an inert shield gas.
18.description: Argon is the third most abundant gas in Earth’s atmosphere.

19.name: Potassium
19.uses: Used in fertilizers, soaps, and as a salt substitute.
19.description: Potassium is a soft, reactive metal essential for biological functions.

20.name: Calcium
20.uses: Used in cement, bones, and as a dietary supplement.
20.description: Calcium is abundant in Earth’s crust and vital for living organisms.

21.name: Scandium
21.uses: Used in aerospace alloys and high-intensity lamps.
21.description: Scandium is a rare-earth metal with a high melting point.

22.name: Titanium
22.uses: Used in aircraft, medical implants, and pigments.
22.description: Titanium is strong, lightweight, and resistant to corrosion.

23.name: Vanadium
23.uses: Used in steel alloys and batteries.
23.description: Vanadium enhances steel strength and is colorful in compounds.

24.name: Chromium
24.uses: Used in stainless steel, chrome plating, and pigments.
24.description: Chromium is known for its luster and corrosion resistance.

25.name: Manganese
25.uses: Used in steel production and batteries.
25.description: Manganese is essential for steelmaking and has multiple oxidation states.

26.name: Iron
26.uses: Used in construction, steel, and machinery.
26.description: Iron is the most widely used metal, forming the Earth’s core.

27.name: Cobalt
27.uses: Used in batteries, alloys, and pigments.
27.description: Cobalt gives a vivid blue color to glass and ceramics.

28.name: Nickel
28.uses: Used in stainless steel, coins, and batteries.
28.description: Nickel is corrosion-resistant and used extensively in alloys.

29.name: Copper
29.uses: Used in wiring, plumbing, and coins.
29.description: Copper is an excellent conductor and one of the first metals used by humans.

30.name: Zinc
30.uses: Used in galvanizing, batteries, and alloys.
30.description: Zinc protects steel from rust and is essential for human health.

31.name: Gallium
31.description: Gallium melts just above room temperature and wets glass.

32.name: Germanium
32.uses: Used in semiconductors and fiber optics.
32.description: Germanium was key in early transistor development.

33.name: Arsenic
33.uses: Used in pesticides, semiconductors, and wood preservatives.
33.description: Arsenic is toxic and has been used historically as a poison.

34.name: Selenium
34.uses: Used in glassmaking, electronics, and as a nutrient.
34.description: Selenium conducts electricity better in light than in dark.

35.name: Bromine
35.uses: Used in flame retardants, disinfectants, and dyes.
35.description: Bromine is one of the few elements liquid at room temperature.

36.name: Krypton
36.description: Krypton emits a greenish glow when electrified.

37.name: Rubidium
37.uses: Used in atomic clocks and research.
37.description: Rubidium ignites spontaneously in air and reacts vigorously with water.

38.name: Strontium
38.uses: Used in fireworks (red color) and medical imaging.
38.description: Strontium resembles calcium and is used for its red flame.

39.name: Yttrium
39.uses: Used in LEDs, lasers, and superconductors.
39.description: Yttrium is often grouped with rare-earth elements.

40.name: Zirconium
40.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and jewelry (zircon).
40.description: Zirconium is corrosion-resistant and used in harsh environments.

41.name: Niobium
41.uses: Used in steel alloys and superconductors.
41.description: Niobium resists corrosion and enhances steel properties.

42.name: Molybdenum
42.uses: Used in steel alloys and catalysts.
42.description: Molybdenum has a high melting point and strengthens steel.

43.name: Technetium
43.description: Technetium is the first synthetic element, radioactive.

44.name: Ruthenium
44.description: Ruthenium is a rare, hard metal in the platinum group.

45.name: Rhodium
45.uses: Used in catalytic converters and jewelry.
45.description: Rhodium is highly reflective and resistant to tarnish.

46.name: Palladium
46.uses: Used in catalytic converters and jewelry.
46.description: Palladium absorbs hydrogen and is valuable in catalysis.

47.name: Silver
47.uses: Used in jewelry, coins, and electronics.
47.description: Silver has the highest electrical conductivity of any metal.

48.name: Cadmium
48.uses: Used in batteries, pigments, and plating.
48.description: Cadmium is toxic and often found with zinc ores.

49.name: Indium
49.description: Indium is soft and malleable, used in electronics.

50.name: Tin
50.uses: Used in solder, tin cans, and alloys like bronze.
50.description: Tin resists corrosion and has been used since ancient times in alloys.

51.name: Antimony
51.uses: Used in flame retardants, alloys, and semiconductors.
51.description: Antimony is brittle and has been used historically in cosmetics and medicine.

52.name: Tellurium
52.uses: Used in solar cells, semiconductors, and alloys.
52.description: Tellurium is brittle and mildly toxic, often found with gold.

53.name: Iodine
53.appearance: Shiny, black solid or violet gas
53.uses: Used in disinfectants, medicine, and photography.
53.description: Iodine sublimates into a violet gas and is essential for thyroid function.

54.name: Xenon
54.uses: Used in lighting, lasers, and anesthesia.
54.description: Xenon emits a blue glow when electrified and is rare in the atmosphere.

55.name: Cesium
55.uses: Used in atomic clocks and photoelectric cells.
55.description: Cesium is highly reactive and used to define the second.

56.name: Barium
56.uses: Used in fireworks (green color) and X-ray imaging.
56.description: Barium is reactive and gives a green flame in tests.

57.name: Lanthanum
57.uses: Used in camera lenses and hybrid car batteries.
57.description: Lanthanum is soft and ductile, marking the start of the lanthanides.

58.name: Cerium
58.uses: Used in catalytic converters, glass polishing, and lighter flints.
58.description: Cerium is the most abundant rare-earth element, soft and reactive.

59.name: Praseodymium
59.uses: Used in magnets, lasers, and glass coloring.
59.description: Praseodymium gives a green color to glass and ceramics.

60.name: Neodymium
60.uses: Used in powerful magnets and lasers.
60.description: Neodymium is key in high-strength magnets for electronics.

61.name: Promethium
61.discoverer: Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Charles D. Coryell
61.uses: Used in nuclear batteries and research.
61.description: Promethium is radioactive and rare, with no stable isotopes.

62.name: Samarium
62.uses: Used in magnets, nuclear reactors, and cancer treatment.
62.description: Samarium is moderately hard and used in high-strength magnets.

63.name: Europium
63.uses: Used in phosphors for TV screens and LEDs.
63.description: Europium is highly reactive and glows red or blue in phosphors.

64.name: Gadolinium
64.uses: Used in MRI contrast agents and nuclear reactors.

65.name: Terbium
65.uses: Used in phosphors and solid-state devices.
65.description: Terbium emits a green glow in phosphors.

66.name: Dysprosium
66.uses: Used in magnets and nuclear reactors.
66.description: Dysprosium has high magnetic strength at high temperatures.

67.name: Holmium
67.uses: Used in magnets and nuclear control rods.
67.description: Holmium has the highest magnetic moment of any element.

68.name: Erbium
68.uses: Used in fiber optics and lasers.
68.description: Erbium gives a pink color to glass and enhances optical fibers.

69.name: Thulium
69.uses: Used in portable X-ray machines and lasers.
69.description: Thulium is one of the rarest lanthanides.

70.name: Ytterbium
70.uses: Used in lasers and as a doping agent.
70.description: Ytterbium is soft and has a bright, silvery luster.

71.name: Lutetium
71.uses: Used in catalysts and medical imaging.
71.description: Lutetium is the last lanthanide, hard and dense.

72.name: Hafnium
72.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and microchips.
72.description: Hafnium is chemically similar to zirconium and very corrosion-resistant.

73.name: Tantalum
73.uses: Used in capacitors and surgical implants.
73.description: Tantalum has a high melting point and resists corrosion.

74.name: Tungsten
74.uses: Used in light bulb filaments and cutting tools.
74.description: Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals.

75.name: Rhenium
75.discoverer: Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack, Otto Berg
75.uses: Used in jet engines and catalysts.
75.description: Rhenium has one of the highest melting points and densities.

76.name: Osmium
76.uses: Used in fountain pen tips and alloys.
76.description: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element.

77.name: Iridium
77.uses: Used in spark plugs and crucibles.
77.description: Iridium is extremely corrosion-resistant and dense.

78.name: Platinum
78.uses: Used in jewelry, catalytic converters, and electronics.
78.description: Platinum is highly unreactive and prized for its rarity.

79.name: Gold
79.uses: Used in jewelry, electronics, and currency.
79.description: Gold is highly malleable and valued for its beauty and rarity.

80.name: Mercury
80.uses: Used in thermometers, barometers, and fluorescent lamps.
80.description: Mercury is the only metal liquid at room temperature.

81.name: Thallium
81.uses: Used in electronics and as a rat poison (historically).
81.description: Thallium is highly toxic and produces a green spectral line.

82.name: Lead
82.uses: Used in batteries, radiation shielding, and pipes (historically).
82.description: Lead is dense, soft, and toxic, with historical use in plumbing.

83.name: Bismuth
83.uses: Used in cosmetics, alloys, and stomach remedies.
83.description: Bismuth has low toxicity and forms iridescent crystals.

84.name: Polonium
84.uses: Used in antistatic devices and research.
84.description: Polonium is highly radioactive and rare.

85.name: Astatine
85.discoverer: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè
85.description: Astatine is extremely rare and radioactive, with no stable isotopes.

86.name: Radon
86.description: Radon is a radioactive gas that can accumulate in buildings.

87.name: Francium
87.description: Francium is extremely rare and radioactive, with a short half-life.

88.name: Radium
88.description: Radium glows faintly and is highly radioactive.

89.name: Actinium
89.uses: Used in research and neutron sources.
89.description: Actinium is radioactive and glows blue in the dark.

90.name: Thorium
90.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and gas mantles.
90.description: Thorium is radioactive and abundant, a potential nuclear fuel.

91.name: Protactinium
91.description: Protactinium is rare, radioactive, and decays into actinium.

92.name: Uranium
92.uses: Used in nuclear reactors and weapons.
92.description: Uranium is radioactive and the primary fuel for nuclear energy.

93.name: Neptunium
93.uses: Used in research and neutron detection.
93.description: Neptunium is synthetic and radioactive, produced in nuclear reactors.

94.name: Plutonium
94.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan
94.uses: Used in nuclear weapons and reactors.
94.description: Plutonium is highly radioactive and toxic, key in nuclear applications.

95.name: Americium
95.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso
95.uses: Used in smoke detectors and research.
95.description: Americium is radioactive and emits alpha particles.

96.name: Curium
96.discoverer: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso
96.uses: Used in space power systems and research.
96.description: Curium is radioactive and glows due to its own heat.

97.name: Berkelium
97.discoverer: Stanley G. Thompson, Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg
97.description: Berkelium is synthetic and radioactive, produced in trace amounts.

98.name: Californium
98.discoverer: Stanley G. Thompson, Kenneth Street Jr., Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg
98.uses: Used in neutron moisture gauges and research.
98.description: Californium is a strong neutron emitter, synthetic and radioactive.

99.name: Einsteinium
99.description: Einsteinium is synthetic and radioactive, discovered in H-bomb fallout.

100.name: Fermium
100.description: Fermium is synthetic and radioactive, with no practical applications.

101.name: Mendelevium
101.description: Mendelevium is synthetic, honoring the periodic table’s creator.

102.name: Nobelium
102.description: Nobelium is synthetic and radioactive, named after the Nobel Prize founder.

103.name: Lawrencium
103.description: Lawrencium marks the end of the actinides, synthetic and radioactive.

104.name: Rutherfordium
104.description: Rutherfordium is a synthetic superheavy element.

105.name: Dubnium
105.description: Dubnium is synthetic and radioactive, with a short half-life.

106.name: Seaborgium
106.description: Seaborgium is synthetic, named after a nuclear chemistry pioneer.

107.name: Bohrium
107.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al. (GSI)
107.description: Bohrium is a synthetic superheavy element named after the physicist Niels Bohr.

108.name: Hassium
108.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al. (GSI)
108.description: Hassium is a synthetic superheavy element, named after the German state of Hesse.

109.name: Meitnerium
109.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al. (GSI)
109.description: Meitnerium is a synthetic element honoring physicist Lise Meitner.

110.name: Darmstadtium
110.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al. (GSI)
110.description: Darmstadtium is a synthetic superheavy element named after its discovery location.

111.name: Roentgenium
111.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al. (GSI)
111.description: Roentgenium is synthetic, named after the discoverer of X-rays.

112.name: Copernicium
112.discoverer: Peter Armbruster, Gottfried Münzenberg et al. (GSI)
112.description: Copernicium is a synthetic element named after the astronomer Copernicus.

113.name: Nihonium
113.description: Nihonium is a synthetic superheavy element discovered in Japan.

114.name: Flerovium
114.description: Flerovium is a synthetic superheavy element named after a nuclear physicist.

115.name: Moscovium
115.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research & Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
115.description: Moscovium is a synthetic superheavy element named after Moscow.

116.name: Livermorium
116.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research & Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
116.description: Livermorium is a synthetic superheavy element named after its discovery lab.

117.name: Tennessine
117.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research & Oak Ridge National Laboratory
117.description: Tennessine is a synthetic superheavy element, likely a halogen.

118.name: Oganesson
118.discoverer: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research & Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
118.description: Oganesson is the heaviest synthetic element, possibly a noble gas.
